[NWFWMDDI-135] Standardize derived Lands_MASTER column names Created: 11/Feb/20  Updated: 16/Mar/20  Resolved: 16/Mar/20

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Database
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

The Region, WMA, and Tract feature classes, along with their "_SINGLE" counterparts, currently follow the Land Management data model standard of storing the object’s name in a column called Name. While this is consistent with the naming of other object types (e.g. Building.Name, Road.Name) it differs from another standard in which all feature classes have leading columns called Region, WMA, and Tract, which contain the names of those respective features.

These feature classes represent a special case, which causes a conflict between these two standards. We need to pick one - and, indeed, we did when designing the original model.

In retrospect, however, we find that every feature class in the data model - excepting only District, to which these values do not apply by definition - includes standardized leading columns with physical names Region, WMA, and Tract for the name of each relevant administrative boundary.

Additionally, with the original standard, columns in these three feature classes with the same semantics have different names:

  • The region name column is called: Region.Name, WMA.Region, and Tract.Region
  • The WMA name column is called: WMA.Name and Tract.WMA

To make these column consistent with the rest of the model, rename the following columns:

Old name New name
Region.Name Region.Region
WMA.Name WMA.WMA
Tract.Name Tract.Tract

Note that the remaining tract columns - Type, Management, and Acres - can remain as-is. These names follow with the new (2020 Q1 release) simplified physical and alias names, and are intuitive within the Tract feature class. They differ from the names in their parent Lands_MASTER feature class, but 1) Lands_MASTER is another special case, and 2) end users do not have access to that feature class, anyway.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 11/Feb/20 ]

Authorized by Danny Layfield on 2020-02-10 phone call

Comment by Michael Mannion [ 11/Feb/20 ]

  1. Changing aliases to remove the word “Name”, for consistency with the rest of the model
  2. Reordering to Region > WMA > Tract, per leading column standards in NWFWMDDI-124

 Description   

As with the column aliases described in NWFWMDDI-126, the physical column names for some columns on the Exotic<type> and TESpecies<type> feature classes have extraneous qualifiers at the start of their names. To improve consistency with the rest of the model, remove these qualifers:

Old name New name
ExoticType Type
ExoticName Name
SpeciesType Type
Species Name
SpeciesLevel TELevel
SpeciesSite Site

Note that “Level” is a reserved geodatabase keyword, which gets remapped automatically to “Level_”. Therefore, we’re using the safe “TELevel” column name, following the domain name, “T&E Level”.

[NWFWMDDI-129] Clarify acres/length column names and aliases Created: 10/Feb/20  Updated: 16/Mar/20  Resolved: 16/Mar/20

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Database
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

Feature Classes in the Land Management data model use a combination of user-assigned and system-assigned values for area and length measurements. In some cases, the names are specific and unambiguous. For example, the Restroom feature class has DeckingLength and RampLength columns. These types of measurements for “small” features (e.g. measurable with a tape measure), especially for sub-properties of the main feature (e.g. decking, railings), are typically named verbosely and clearly.

In other cases, an unqualified name is used. In the Culvert feature class, for instance, the length value column is simply named Length, with an alias of “Length (ft)”. Nonetheless, this is unambiguously a user-assigned value, because Culvert is a point feature class (i.e. there is no system-assigned length for a point).

Many times, however, the plain column name Length and alias “Length (ft)” are used for system-assigned values. In the BoundaryMarking feature class, we have both LengthEstimate and Length columns. Within the context of that table, it is clear that LengthEstimate should be entered by the user, and relatively easy to infer that Length would be computed automatically by the software. Across the whole model, though, the semantics for columns named Length differ and, in turn, are not clear. Even in the BoundaryMarking case, further clarifying that the Length column is system-assigned would not hurt.

(Similar examples exist for columns named Acres and AcresEstimate throughout the model.)

To clarify the meaning of the various length and area columns:

  • For system-assigned values:
    • Rename the physical column Length to SystemLength, and set its alias to “System Length (<units>)”
    • Rename the physical column Acres to SystemAcres, and set its alias to “System Acres”
  • For user-assigned values:
    • For physical columns with “Estimate” in the name, ensure that the alias also includes the word “Estimate”
    • For physical columns with the bare name Length or Acres, evaluate whether adding a qualifier (e.g. “Estimate”) would remove ambiguity. Implement changes to clarify, if and only if appropriate. Note that this directive does not prefer either renaming these columns, nor or leaving them as-is. Do what makes sense, bearing in mind that the simple column names are sometimes the best choice (e.g. PicnicTable.Length is both more clear and more correct than something like PicnicTable.LengthEstimate.)
    • Review and updated aliases to clarify, when appropriate

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 10/Feb/20 ]

Approved by Danny Layfield in 2020-02-10 phone call

Comment by Michael Mannion [ 10/Feb/20 ]

Leaving Boardwalk.LengthEstimate alias as "Boardwalk Length (ft)", without adding "Estimate". Reasons are:

  • The alias will be quite long with the extra word
  • In the context of the aliases for the other user-maintained measurement columns (“Post Spacing (ft)”, “Railing Height (ft)”, “Boardwalk Width (ft)”) it is more consistent to keep the existing name.
  • Because we are renaming the system-maintained length columns to SystemLength with aliases “System Length”, it will be sufficiently clear what each column means.

In this case, adding “Estimate” to the alias, just to comply with the new standard, would do more harm than good.

Time Spent: Not Specified

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 10/Feb/20 ]

Approved by Danny Layfield in 2020-02-10 phone call. Rationale is as follows:

  • If we update the reporting views to match the new underlying table schemas, dependents will need to be ported to the new views, anyway. So, less overall effort to just port them directly to the new tables now.
  • Alternatively, we could update the views to keep the same old view schema, to avoid having to update dependents now. But, this would only be a temporary measure, so the effort would be better spent in porting the dependents to the new tables (i.e. the target final solution).
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 11/Feb/20 ]

For posterity, here is the structure of a generic asset reporting proxy view. Note the following:

  • Subtype CTE that parses geodatabase metadata XML
  • Join to Tract_SINGLE (one feature per tract) feature class to pick up WMA attribute (including join using decoded subtype data)
  • SystemLength and SystemAcres computations (from existing projected coordinates in meters)
  • Archive timestamp predicates
WITH
	subtype (
		code
		,description
	)
	AS (
		SELECT
			definition.subtype.value('SubtypeCode[1]', 'INT')
			,definition.subtype.value('SubtypeName[1]', 'VARCHAR(MAX)')
		FROM sde.gdb_items i
		CROSS APPLY i.definition.nodes('/DEFeatureClassInfo/Subtypes/Subtype') AS definition(subtype)
		WHERE
			LOWER(i.physicalname) = 'gis.gis.featureclass'
	)
SELECT
	fc.shape "Shape"
	,fc.objectid "ObjectID"
	,fc.globalid "GlobalID"
	,subtype.description "Region"
	,tract_single.wma "WMA"
	,fc.tract "Tract"
	.
	.
	.
	,fc.shape.STLength() * 3.28084 "SystemLength"
	,fc.shape.STArea() * 0.000247105 "SystemAcres"
FROM gis.easement fc
LEFT JOIN subtype ON
	fc.region = subtype.code
LEFT JOIN gis.tract_single ON
	subtype.description = tract_single.region
	AND fc.tract = tract_single.tract
WHERE
	fc.gdb_from_date <= SYSDATETIMEOFFSET()
	AND fc.gdb_to_date > SYSDATETIMEOFFSET()

[NWFWMDDI-126] Shorten column aliases that are prefixed with the table name Created: 08/Feb/20  Updated: 16/Mar/20  Resolved: 16/Mar/20

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Database
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified

Issue links:
Blocks
is blocked by NWFWMDDI-124 Standardize order of common columns i... Done
is blocked by NWFWMDDI-125 Standardize status columns in Land Ma... Done

 Description   

Various ArcGIS clients display geodatabase column aliases to end users, instead of the physical column names. Shorter aliases are generally better, because they save screen real estate for small screens/dialogs, and simplify complex interfaces when working with tables containing many columns. Ideally, aliases should be as short as possible, without introducing ambiguity regarding their meaning.

The Land Management data model contains many column aliases that include the name of the table (or a variant of the table name). For example, the WasteContainer.Type column is aliased to "Waste Container Type". Simplifying the alias to “Type” retains the same semantics within the context of the WasteContainer table, with a considerably shorter text string.

When evaluating column aliases, preserve the table name prefix in cases where removing the prefix would reduce clarity. Examples include (but are not limited to):

  • Boardwalk - The alias “Railing Height (ft)” is immediately followed by two columns aliases as “Boardwalk Length (ft)” and “Boardwalk Width (ft)”. Because multiple facets of the boardwalk are being measured (railing vs. deck), and because all three columns appear together, it is necessary to preserve the “Boardwalk” alias prefixes to clearly differentiate those measurements from the railing measurement.
  • FenceMaintenancePoint - This feature class has a nearly identical schema to the Fence feature class. For Fence aliases, the “Fence” prefix has been removed from all aliases. In the case of FenceMaintenancePoint, however, we preserve the “Fence” prefixes to designate that some attributes pertain to the fence, itself, and not to a maintenance activity on that fence.
  • NotficationPoint - NWFWMDDI-125 describes adding prefixes to status columns to disambiguate them. In the case of the NotificationPoint feature class, we preserve the more verbose alias “Notification Status” in accord with the new standard set by that ticket. Additionally, the underlying physical column name is NotificationStatus; generally speaking, if an alias can be shorter than the physical column name without being ambiguous, the physical column name likely needs to be simplified, as well. (In this case, using the longer physical name NotificationStatus and alias “Notification Status” remove ambiguity when considering the model as a whole, even though the prefixes are arguably unnecessary within the more narrow context of this one feature class.)
  • Pavilion - Contrary to the prior bullet, the “Pavilion Number” alias could be shortened to “Number” while retaining sufficient clarity. Because “number” is a SQL reserved keyword, however, the physical column is named PavilionNumber. We could keep the necessarily-verbose physical name and still choose a shorter alias name. This case (along with{{Campsite.CampsiteNumber}}, “Campsite Number”) could be justified equally either way. Here, we choose the longer names because, conversationally, users tend to the longer names because the word “number” is, itself, so generic (compare “number” with “ID”, for example; the former may denote a quantity or an ID-type name, whereas the latter is unequivocally a moniker.)

To summarize: Strive to shorten aliases in all cases, but make infrequent exceptions when judgement dictates that preserving a longer name is necessary for functional clarity.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 08/Feb/20 ]

Authorized by Danny Layfield in 2020-02-06 phone call

[NWFWMDDI-125] Standardize status columns in Land Management data model Created: 07/Feb/20  Updated: 16/Mar/20  Resolved: 16/Mar/20

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Database
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified

Issue links:
Blocks
blocks NWFWMDDI-114 Add column to RoadMaintenance feature... Done
blocks NWFWMDDI-124 Standardize order of common columns i... Done
blocks NWFWMDDI-126 Shorten column aliases that are prefi... Done

 Description   

The Land Management data model uses a variety of status-related columns (columns with "status" in their name). When more than one status column is present in a table, one or more of the column names are prefixed to indicate their meaning. For example, the proposed ApiarySite table has LeaseStatus and AccessStatus columns.

The unadorned name “Status” is used frequently throughout the model, however, often with different semantics. Most commonly, columns named “Status” will use either the Access Status or Assessment Status domain. The meaning of the column is not always evident from its context alone, requiring designers (and presumably end users; these are not largely deployed yet) to reference the domain values to understand the column’s purpose.

Therefore, rename any columns with the name “Status” to include a prefix that describes the type of status that they represent.

[NWFWMDDI-124] Standardize order of common columns in Land Management model Created: 07/Feb/20  Updated: 16/Mar/20  Resolved: 16/Mar/20

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Database
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified

Issue links:
Blocks
blocks NWFWMDDI-126 Shorten column aliases that are prefi... Done
is blocked by NWFWMDDI-125 Standardize status columns in Land Ma... Done

 Description   

As the Land Management data model evolves, patterns are emerging about additional common columns that are used frequently. While their definitions in the development spreadsheet (Lands Collection Data Dictionary Master.xlsx) are generally consistent, their column order within the respective tables are not.

Adding additional column definitions / orders to those that are already established will facilitate developing (spreadsheet) and deploying (code) future data model updates.

Tasks include:

  1. Identify columns that are commonly used among existing and newly-proposed (2020 Q1 release) tables
  2. Determine a standard definition and order, for columns that are not already standardized
  3. Document the standard
  4. Update the development spreadsheet to reflect the new standard
  5. Update master deployment script (create_lands_data_model.py) to physically enforce the standard during the next deployment

Note that existing columns with standard orders are only found at the beginning and end of the table. Expanding this standard will involve columns in the middle, where per-table idiosyncrasies are expected and necessary. While the relative order of standardized columns should not change, table-specific columns should be allowed to intervene among them.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 07/Feb/20 ]

Authorized by Danny on 2020-02-06 phone call




[NWFWMDDI-123] Convert reporting views to triggers Created: 07/Feb/20  Updated: 16/Mar/20  Resolved: 16/Mar/20

Key
 Summary
 Type
 Status
 Assignee
NWFWMDDI-128 Remove reporting views from Land Mana... Sub-task Done Michael Mannion  

 Description   

Because of the increasing importance of geodatabase attachments to NWFWMD end users, and ongoing lack of support for using attachments with views in ArcGIS (see GeoNet post here), we decided in a 2020-02-06 Land Management data model status meeting to migrate away from the existing reporting views ("<table>_R"), to trigger-maintained columns on the base tables.

This is the top-level issue for coordinating this work. Table-specific implementation tasks should be added as subtasks under this parent. Generic work (e.g. research) should be logged in this task.

The scope of the effort includes:

  1. Developing a general solution for using triggers with archive-enabled, non-versioned geodatabase (10.6) tables in SQL Server.
  2. Apply solution to new tables created in the 2020 Q1 data model release
  3. Apply solution to existing tables in the Land Management data model

Item 1 above can build on recent trigger work for the GIS.DATABASES_ORPHAN_WELLS in the Oracle geodatabase. Verify that the logic is the same, and port existing code from PL/SQL to T-SQL.

Items 2 and 3 require several steps:

  • Add formerly-view-only columns to the base tables
  • Populate existing rows (active and archived) with values for the new columns
  • Create triggers to maintain the values going forward

For tables with existing reporting views, leave the views in-place until dependents have fully migrated to the new trigger-maintained columns.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 07/Feb/20 ]

Authorized by Danny Layfield in 2020-02-06 phone call.

Comment by Michael Mannion [ 04/Mar/20 ]

The trigger implementation includes T-SQL variables declared as user-defined data types (UDT). This code executes successfully through SSMS, but fails through arcpy.ArcSDESQLExecute().execute().

Therefore, the creation workflow now uses three scripts, rather than one:

  • create_lands_data_model.1.sql
  • create_lands_data_model.2.py < Originally create_lands_data_model.py
  • create_lands_data_model.3.sql

Run these three scripts in order, in their respective appropriate environment (note file extensions).

[NWFWMDDI-119] Expose boundary constants from GIS.GIS_REFRESH package Created: 09/Jan/20  Updated: 09/Jan/20  Resolved: 09/Jan/20

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Database, Replication
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Task Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

The GIS.GIS_REFRESH package uses a (buffered) bounding rectangle around the NWFWMD boundary, outside of which coordinates harvested from other business systems are considered to be categorically invalid. These coordinates are stored as envelope constants, for each of three coordinate systems:

ORDINATE_DD_XMAX
ORDINATE_DD_XMIN
ORDINATE_DD_YMAX
ORDINATE_DD_YMIN

ORDINATE_DMS_XMAX
ORDINATE_DMS_XMIN
ORDINATE_DMS_YMAX
ORDINATE_DMS_YMIN

ORDINATE_UTM_XMAX
ORDINATE_UTM_XMIN
ORDINATE_UTM_YMAX
ORDINATE_UTM_YMIN

Occasionally, SQL statements and PL/SQL blocks outside of the GIS.GIS_REFRESH package need access to these constants. Oracle, however, does not support direct access of package constants from outside of the package. As a result, we need a getter function(s) that allow external statements to use these values.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 09/Jan/20 ]

Authorized indirectly via 2020-01-07 meeting with Danny / Shawn / Tom per tasking to produce missing well permit reports for user review.

[NWFWMDDI-91] Replicate CUPBND_SDE from SJRWMD to NWFWMD Created: 02/Dec/19  Updated: 07/Dec/19  Resolved: 07/Dec/19

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Replication
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Task Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

Maps and services that use the PDSLIB.CUPBND_SDE feature class directly from the remote NWSDE geodatabase, hosted at St. Johns, suffer from poor performance due to limited bandwidth and unstable connectivity between the two sites. Therefore, create and maintain a local copy of that data set in a local (to NWFWMD) enterprise geodatabase.

The local copy should be refreshed at least daily. Other than that, there are no specific business requirements.

In the context of this ticket, "replication" does not denote any specific technology; any solution that is able to maintain the local copy with reasonable stability, simplicity, and efficiency will suffice.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 02/Dec/19 ]
  • Per recent phone call with Danny and Shawn, refresh the local copy on the existing six-hour schedule used for other SJRWMD > NWFWMD replication tasks. This keeps things logically simple, and affords multiple opportunities to update the data set each day, in the event that any given attempt fails.
  • The local copy will be online and in-use by services and other maps during the refresh attempts. Expect geodatabase locks to be present.
  • The refresh operation is atomic; it should succeed or fail as a whole, and leave a usable local copy regardless of the status of each refresh attempt.
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 02/Dec/19 ]

See code / comments in aquarius2gdb.py for example of implementing a kill-and-fill refresh with arcpy at the current release (10.6). Also review documentation feedback to Esri in OneNote (“ArcGIS doc feedback” page).




[NWFWMDDI-90] Display both old and new style related permit numbers in GIS.DATABASES_WELL_PERMITS Created: 05/Sep/19  Updated: 18/Dec/19  Resolved: 18/Dec/19

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Replication
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

A well permit can optionally have a related permit(s). The related permit is identified by either one or two permit numbers, each using a potentially different format.

Related permits are stored in the REGUSER.RLTD_PROJ table. Though not enforced in the database, all permits appear to have a text value stored in the RLTD_TXT column. These values are typically legacy-style permit numbers.

Some permits also have an RLTD_CUR_ID value, which can be resolved to a new-style FULL_APP_NO (via RLTD_PROJ.RLTD_CUR_ID = REG_PROJ_ET.CUR_ID).

Currently, in our GIS.DATABASES_WELL_PERMITS table, we are only storing the new-style permit numbers. This differs from what users see in the eReg UI. This can also lead to confusion when RLTD_CUR_ID is NULL, because the value that differentiates two "duplicate" rows (RLTD_TXT) is not included in DATABASES_WELL_PERMITS, so users end up seeing two identical rows (both with a NULL value for RELATED_PERMIT).

Per 2019-09-05 phone call with Yamila, we should display both related permit values:

  • RLTD_CUR_ID, resolved to FULL_APP_NO
  • RLTD_TXT

To match the legacy well permitting system in ORCL, use the column names RELATED_PERMIT_1 and RELATED_PERMIT_2 respectively.

To implement, we need to:

  • In create_feature_classes_system_integration.py, for function create_databases_well_permits()
    • Rename RELATED_PERMIT to RELATED_PERMIT_1
    • Add a column RELATED_PERMIT_2
  • In create_package_gis_refresh.sql, update procedure{{REFRESH_DATABASES_WELL_PERMITS}} accordingly



[NWFWMDDI-89] Update GIS.GIS_REFRESH.GET_LOCATION_METHOD value mapping Created: 30/Aug/19  Updated: 18/Dec/19  Resolved: 31/Aug/19

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Replication
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

Per 2019-08-30 email from Yamila ("RE: test check"):

With the SJR db they have a lot of options. when the driller enters a location they use a mapping tool to plot the location. SJR classifies this as digitize. So let’s decode … digitize = digitize, any GPS = GPS, all others = others

Our current logic in GIS.GIS_REFRESH.GET_LOCATION_METHOD is:

CASE UPPER(location_method)
	WHEN 'GPS1'		THEN 'GPS'
	WHEN 'GPS2'		THEN 'GPS'
	WHEN 'GPS3'		THEN 'GPS'
	WHEN 'GPS3S'		THEN 'GPS'
	WHEN 'GPS4'		THEN 'GPS'
	WHEN 'CONTROL SURVEY'	THEN 'Other'
	WHEN 'DIGITIZE'		THEN 'Other'
	WHEN 'MAP'		THEN 'Other'
	WHEN 'OTHER/UNKNOWN'	THEN 'Other'
	WHEN 'RESOURCE SURVEY'	THEN 'Other'
	ELSE NULL
END;

Update the output for the input value DIGITIZE from 'Other' to 'Digitize'.

Dependents

Also need to verify/fix column widths for dependent tables that store output values from GET_LOCATION_METHOD. (Standardize on 16 characters)

Table Original width New width
DATABASES_REG_STATION 5 16
DATABASES_WELL_PERMITS 100 16

[NWFWMDDI-87] Change CSV encoding to Unicode Created: 30/May/19  Updated: 31/May/19  Resolved: 31/May/19

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: FEMA Reporting
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Bug Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified

Attachments: 2019-05-30_email.pdf    

 Description   

The export_fema_inspection.py script uses the Python 2.7.14 open() function to open the output CSV file. This function assumes ASCII encoding, so attempts to write Unicode characters outside of the ASCII range will raise an error (see first email in thread in attachment (2019-05-30_email.pdf).

The version of iOS on which field users are currently running Collector replaces normal quotes with “smart quotes” by default (Settings > General > Keyboard > Smart Punctuation). For at least this reason, we need to write the output CSV with an encoding scheme that can handle Unicode characters outside of the ASCII range.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 30/May/19 ]

Authorized 2019-05-30 by Danny via email/phone

Comment by Michael Mannion [ 30/May/19 ]

For output CSV file, changed open() to io.open(encoding=u'utf-8').

Also updated open() call for binary files (i.e. attachments) to use io.open(), for consistency.




[NWFWMDDI-86] Add object ID as Type suffix Created: 29/May/19  Updated: 31/May/19  Resolved: 31/May/19

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: FEMA Reporting
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

The FEMA Grants Manager system does not preserve all of the information from the output CSV file that we create. Additionally, the information that is preserved is not structured in the same way. Either of these circumstances can lead to ambiguity / confusion for Grants Manager users when reviewing NWFWMD content related to Hurricane Michael.

To facilitate the ability to differentiate between assets of the same type, particularly unnamed assets, include the assets' respective object IDs as part of the Type output column, in the following format:

<type> <objectid>

where:

  • <type> - Existing asset type value
  • <objectid> - Asset object ID

In short, suffix the existing Type values with the object ID, separated by a space.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 29/May/19 ]

Authorized in 2019-05-29 phone call with Danny

[NWFWMDDI-81] Rewrite attachment names on export Created: 24/May/19  Updated: 31/May/19  Resolved: 31/May/19

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: FEMA Reporting
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

When exporting attachments for Hurricane Michael reporting, rename the exported files as follows:

<zone> <type> <asset_objectid> Photo <attachment_objectid><extension>

where:

  • <zone> - The value of the Zone output column, without the word “FEMA” (and it’s adjacent space)
  • <type> - The value of the Type column
  • <asset_objectid> - The object ID of the asset
  • Photo - The literal string “Photo”
  • <objectid> - The object ID of the attachment
  • <extension> - If present, the last dot in the file name, and any text following it (e.g. “.jpg”)

Additionally, rename the asset-specific attachment directory to use object ID instead of global ID.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 28/May/19 ]

Replaced <recreation_site> with <type>, per 2019-05-28 phone call with Danny.

For assets with no recreation site name, we build a name from its zone and WMA attributes (NWFWMDDI-77). Using the originally-proposed file renaming pattern, these sites would end up with the zone in their attachment filenames twice. Using type avoids that redundancy, and makes the files easier to interpret when used outside of the context of the exporter’s directory hierarchy (e.g. as email attachment).

Comment by Michael Mannion [ 29/May/19 ]

Added <asset_objectid>, per 2019-05-29 phone call with Danny.

[NWFWMDDI-79] Remove the "Length (feet)" column from CSV output Created: 24/May/19  Updated: 31/May/19  Resolved: 31/May/19

 Description   

The original Hurricane Michael damage reports for linear features included the actual length of the feature, plus an written estimate in the comments about how much of the feature was damaged, expressed as a percentage. FEMA has requested that we report the only the length of the damage, in units of feet.

[NWFWMDDI-78] In "Type" column, replace instances of the word "Maintenance" with "Damage" Created: 24/May/19  Updated: 31/May/19  Resolved: 31/May/19

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: FEMA Reporting
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Done Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

In the Land Management data model, we use the word "maintenance" in the names of some feature classes (e.g. "Road Maintenance (line)") and, in turn, use those names to describe the type of damaged asset when generating FEMA reports.

The semantics of the term "maintenance", however, differ between the NWFWMD and FEMA environments. Using these literal feature class names in Hurricane Michael damage reports implies the wrong workflow for the target audience at FEMA. Therefore, change all instances of the word "maintenance" to the word "damage" in the output Type column.

[NWFWMDDI-75] Create trigger to assign GIS.DATABASES_ORPHAN_WELLS.REF_NUM values Created: 10/May/19  Updated: 02/Dec/19  Resolved: 02/Dec/19

Status: Done

 Description   

Business Case

In the orcl geodatabase, create a trigger to assign GIS.DATABASES_ORPHAN_WELLS.REF_NUM values.

The format of the values is LB_nnnn_, where:

  • LB - String literal
  • nnnn - Four digit, zero-padded, unique, sequential, integer ID

The current workflow is for end users to create orphaned wells in Web AppBuilder, then for Jarret to subsequently, manually assign the REF_NUM. The goal is to automate this process, such that REF_NUM values are assigned automatically immediately.

The GIS.DATABASES_ORPHANED_WELLS table is the table-of-record for REF_NUM values. Other business processes/systems reference these values. Therefore, values must be static once they are assigned.

REF_NUM values are visible, but not editable, through the web app. Note that this is enforced through the web app, itself; users with the ability to edit through the app have permissions to edit all columns through the underlying (secure) feature service. The app configuration, however, disables editing on the REF_NUM column.

Optional

Explore the possibility of allowing an administrator to override the trigger-assigned REF_NUM value through ArcMap.

Environment

Property Value
Database orcl.nwfwmd.state.fl.us
Table GIS.DATABASES_ORPHAN_WELLS
Column REF_NUM
Service Feature_Services/Orphan_Wells
Web map Orphan Wells Map
Web app Users navigate from:
  • Compass main page
  • GIS Map Services (tile in middle of page)
  • Interactive Map Services (tile at top of page)
  • Orphan Wells link
    Note that this app is hosted on AGOL. There is also a custom app deployed to IIS on gis-prod, but that one is just left over from earlier development / testing.

 Description   

Per the attached 2019-02-27 email from Yamila, set the REVIEW_DATE values in the GIS.DATABASES_ERP_SITE% derived feature classes to NULL while source data issues are being resolved with SJRWMD.

UPDATE

Per 2019-12-28 email from Jarret, we will preserve values for all three DATE columns (EXPIRATION_DATE, ISSUE_DATE, REVIEW_DATE) that ArcGIS considers valid, and set invalid dates to NULL.

Additional research today has not yielded documentation stating a limit for the minimum (or maximum) DATE value that ArcGIS considers valid. I opened Esri Support case 02277188 to investigate.

In the meantime, we’ll deploy an update to GIS.GIS_REFRESH.REFRESH_DATABASES_ERP_SITE to set dates < year 100 to NULL.

Esri Support confirmed that there are two known issues for date values before the year 100. See attached email (2019-02-28_esri_support_email.pdf) for details.

[NWFWMDDI-69] Add user name table Created: 22/May/18  Updated: 22/May/18  Resolved: 22/May/18

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: None
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Task Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Fixed Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

New business requirements are emerging for dashboard users to have the ability to pick a username from a list in order to apply a filter. For example, the dashboard user may want to see all gates, recreation points, and roads added by the user HQ\j_doe, as indicated by Editor Tracking.

One solution would be to scan the editor tracking fields on all relevant feature classes in order to derive the values for the filter pick list. This approach has three drawbacks, however:

  • Performance - Scanning all records in the entire data model (now approaching two-dozen feature classes, with additional growth anticipated in the near term) is slow, and will be increasingly so as time goes on
  • Completeness - The dashboard user may want to pick a username who has not yet created/edited any rows (perhaps to specifically discover that fact)
  • Temporal scope - Requirements are unclear as to whether a pick list based on this method would include only editor names for current rows, or for historical rows as well

Instead, a more flexible solution is to maintain a table of user names that can be used for populating the filter pick lists. While this requires an additional database object, as well as a workflow for maintaining its contents, this overhead is minimal, especially in light of the increased flexibility/functionality.

For now, create a simple table that just stores the user names (along with any requisite geodatabase metadata columns). Although we expect to add addition information (e.g. department) in the future, the requirements are not clear enough to design a more robust solution at this time.

[NWFWMDDI-59] Configure master Tract feature class and derived WMA/Region/District polygons Created: 21/Sep/17  Updated: 26/Sep/17  Resolved: 26/Sep/17

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Database
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Task Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Fixed Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified

Issue links:
Blocks
blocks NWFWMDDI-60 Create feature count summary views fo... Done

 Description   

We have various cartographic and analytic needs for several, hierarchical polygon feature classes whose shared boundaries are consistent among the group:

  • District
  • Region
  • Water management area
  • Tract

The current workflow for maintaining these boundaries uses a single, space-exhaustive, non-overlapping, polygon feature class that tessellates the District into these various sub-areas. From that master feature class, we can derive a consistent set of the four aforementioned themes.

Our goals here are to:

  1. Migrate the master shapefile into the enterprise geodatabase, as Lands_MASTER, and maintain that new copy as the table-of-record going forward
  2. Add or update eight feature classes to the Land Management data mode, whose contents will be derived from Lands_MASTER:
    • One row per contiguous area (i.e. single-part polygons):
      • District
      • Region
      • WMA
      • Tract feature class already exists, but requires updates for consistency with new counterparts:
        • Remove domains
        • Revoke write privileges from mapserver
    • One row per logical feature (i.e. multi-part polygons):
      • District_SINGLE
      • Region_SINGLE
      • WMA_SINGLE
      • Tract_SINGLE
  3. Design a workflow for extracting polygons for each theme from the master feature class and replacing the contents of the existing eight sub-feature classes

The reason that we create two feature classes for each theme is to support summary reports at different levels of detail. For example, one anticipated use case is to allow users to compare expenditures per-parcel within a WMA over the course of a three-year management plan. A second use case is to report total expenditures for the WMA. To facilitate development using Operations Dashboards for ArcGIS, it is easiest to have two separate WMA-related feature classes - one with a polygon per-parcel, and another with one polygon per-WMA.

Note also that the eight derived feature classes should:

  • Be read-only
  • Not have domains

The applicable domains will be present on Lands_MASTER, but are not required on the derived feature classes, because those will not be edited. Omitting them will facilitate future updates to the domains, themselves, because we will not need to un-associate them from these feature classes.

    • Created script tool NWFWMD_10.2.tbx\Land Management\Parse Lands Master to backup > truncate > refresh contents of derived feature classes from current Lands_MASTER

[NWFWMDDI-55] Migrate tract-related attributes to stand-alone table Created: 31/Jul/17  Updated: 04/Aug/17  Resolved: 04/Aug/17

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Database
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Task Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Fixed Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

Per our 2017-07-26 weekly meeting, we determined that tract-related attribute information was:

  1. Duplicated in multiple tables, and within some tables, requiring double-entry and inviting inconsistency
  2. Modeled improperly - Conservation Easements are being treated as subordinate to tracts, rather than as a type of tract
  3. Modeled incompletely - Mitigation tracts were not identifiable via the current 10 Land Management feature classes

Correspondingly - and along with further discussion about the purpose, provenance, and direction of the BOUNDARY_DISTRICT_LANDS feature class - we concluded that the appropriate resolution to these various issues was to:

  1. Create a stand-alone table of (most) tract attributes
  2. Update the BOUNDARY_DISTRICT_LANDS feature class to include polygon detail at the tract level
  3. Derive generalized district lands feature classes from this more detailed one (likely using Dissolve)
  4. Create a relationship class between the tract attribute table and the BOUNDARY_DISTRICT_LANDS feature class
  5. Create map services to support reporting workflows that join the 10 Land Management feature classes to the tract attribute table, when additional attributes are required
  6. Remove the _WMA _and _ConservationEasement _attributes and their corresponding domains from the 10 Land Management feature classes

Update the following artifacts to reflect these changes:

  • Data model diagram
  • Data model spreadsheet
  • Python object creation script
  • Python object deletion script
  • Existing geodatabase domains
  • Existing geodatabase feature classes

 Description   

The Ground Water Regulation web app includes a search tool that allows users to find features via attribute queries. Currently the following columns are available for search:

Map service layer ID Map service layer name Table name Table column From SJRWMD
1 Well Inventory GIS.DATABASES_WELL_INVENTORY NWF_ID Yes
1 Well Inventory GIS.DATABASES_WELL_INVENTORY STATE_ID Yes
2 Well Permits GIS.DATABASES_WELL_PERMITS PERMIT_NUMBER Yes
2 Well Permits GIS.DATABASES_WELL_PERMITS FLUWID Yes
3 WUP Stations GIS.DATABASES_REG_STATION LEGACY_PERMIT_NUMBER Yes
3 WUP Stations GIS.DATABASES_REG_STATION FLUWID Yes
4 Orphan Wells GIS.DATABASES_ORPHAN_WELLS FLUWID No
67 Parcels GIS.PARCELS_DISTRICT PARNO No
69 Sections GIS.BASE_PLSS DESCRIPT No

Entries marked as From SJRWMD represent tables that are stored in the NWFWMD enterprise geodabase, but whose contents are cached from remote tables in an SJRWMD database. As a result, we need to take care to re-create these attribute indexes when we re-create their tables, as is periodically required for implementing newly requested schema changes. Therefore:

  • Add actions to the create_feature_classes_system_integration.py script to create attribute indexes for the relevant columns identified in the table above

Note that source tables with multiple searchable columns are searched by each column individually. Correspondingly, we should create a single-column index for each searchable column.

62-330 DATABASES_ERP_SITE_62_330 62-330 ERP Conceptual
ERP Formal Wetland Determination
ERP General

ERP Permit Determination/Exemption

In each case, we will drop the PARTY_% columns to avoid creating duplicate rows for each site during joins (assuming no other 1:M relationships in the underlying data).

[NWFWMDDI-37] For GIS.DATABASES_ERP_SITE, assume input rows with NULL CRDNT_CD are DMS Created: 28/Oct/15  Updated: 28/Oct/15  Resolved: 28/Oct/15

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Replication
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Task Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Fixed Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

When constructing the GIS.DATABASES_ERP_SITE feature class, we refrain from attempting to construct shapes for input data that does not have a valid REGUSER.PROJ_SITE.CRDNT_CD value. While eReg appears to store a CRDNT_CD for all new rows, the legacy system used DMS exclusively and, consequently, did not store an equivalent to the CRDNT_CD column explicitly. During migration, the legacy MSSW (and possibly other) data received NULL CRDNT_CD values, so even those features that have valid longitude/latitude values will not have shapes created during refresh.

  • Change the sql_sr_dms filter to include rows with NULL CRDNT_CD values, and;
  • Make the corresponding change to exclude those rows from the sql_sr_invalid filter

[NWFWMDDI-32] Refresh during ArcMap session breaks attribute tables Created: 28/Sep/15  Updated: 16/Nov/15  Resolved: 28/Sep/15

Status: To Do
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Replication
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Critical
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Unresolved Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified

Attachments: loading_table_data_error.png    

 Description   

In scenarios where an active ArcMap session references a feature class whose contents are refreshed using a GIS.GIS_REFRESH.REFRESH_DATABASES_% job, errors can occur with the ArcMap session. The attached "loading_table_data_error.png" image shows one example that arises when viewing an attribute table. Similarly, large feature selections (> 100 features) can spontaneously disappear with no error.

In both cases, the problems are caused by the (effective) change in the OBJECTID values of the underlying features. The refresh procedures update the target feature classes by deleting the existing rows and repopulating the tables with the current state of the data from the source database (NWPROD). This includes reloading all unchanged rows, in addition to any new or modified rows. Correspondingly, all OBJECTID values in the table after the refresh are new, and any ArcMap (or other client) functionality that relies on OBJECTIDs will be prone to experiencing problems.

We need to find a workable solution that eliminates, or at least minimizes, the impact on the end users. Solutions may include:

  • Refreshing using MERGE instead of DELETE > INSERT (requires unique ID to determine whether row has changed or not)
  • Updating using versioning (assuming we can compress large volumes of deltas without disconnecting users / map services)
  • Configuring feature classes with user-managed ArcSDE row ID value (also requires that we have, or can reliably generate, static unique IDs for each row)

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 16/Nov/15 ]

Changed refresh interval from 1 hour to 6 hours for jobs:

  • GIS: REFRESH ERP_SITE
  • GIS: REFRESH REG_STATION
    This isn't a permanent solution, but will help mitigate errors until we find one.



[NWFWMDDI-31] Configure Database Control notifications for failed refresh jobs Created: 28/Sep/15  Updated: 28/Sep/15  Resolved: 28/Sep/15

Status: To Do

Affects versions: None

Resolution: Unresolved Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

The Oracle Scheduler logs GIS refresh job failures, but currently administrators need to manually check the results of previously executed jobs. Database Control supports sending email (and other) notifications to administrators, and ORCL is configured to send email properly through an SMTP service.

Although test messages can be sent and received successfully, Database Control will not send alert notifications unless the Diagnostics Pack is licensed and activated. Currently, Diagnostics Pack is not activated. I sent an email to James today to ask whether the District has a license. If so, we need to enable the Diagnostics Pack (Database Control > Setup > Management Pack Access). Otherwise, administrators will need to remember to check for job failures periodically.



[NWFWMDDI-30] Limit GIS.DATABASES_STATION.LEGACY_APNUM to actual values used in legacy system Created: 28/Sep/15  Updated: 28/Sep/15  Resolved: 28/Sep/15

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Replication
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Task Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Fixed Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

During migration, the WUP.CU_APP.APNUM values were migrated to the REGUSER.REG_PROJ_ET.CUR_ID column as-is. ERP and MSSW records received new CUR_ID values, beginning with the next sequence number. Likewise, new records of any sort are assigned new, incrementing CUR_ID values from the same sequence.

Some NWFWMD users have requested the inclusion of the original APNUM value as an attribute on the GIS.DATABASES_STATION feature class, in order to correlate data from the new system with various legacy records. The LEGACY_APNUM column contains this data, and is populated with REGUSER.REG_PROJ_ET.CUR_ID values from the new system.

Presently, however, LEGACY_APNUM contains a CUR_ID for every row in GIS.DATABASES_STATION - including both legacy and newly-created records. To avoid confusion, we should limit the LEGACY_APNUM values to only those that actually correspond to records from the old system, and exclude CUR_IDs that were generated within NWPROD/eReg.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 28/Sep/15 ]

Added cutoff for LEGACY_APNUM values:

-- Excerpt from GIS.GIS_REFRESH.REFRESH_DATABASES_STATION
,CASE -- Limit CUR_IDs to values migrated from legacy system
	WHEN rpe.cur_id <= 7541 THEN rpe.cur_id
	ELSE NULL
END legacy_apnum

Relates
relates to NWFWMDDI-33 In GIS.DATABASES_STATION, change PROJ... Done
relates to NWFWMDDI-34 Add GIS.DATABASES_STATION.PROJECT_SEC... Done

 Description   

We currently populate the GIS.DATABASES_STATION.STATION_ALLOCATION_GPD column from the REGUSER.PROJ_ALLOC_SITE_SRCE_STN table. Specifically, for a given Site / Water Source / Station combination, we average ALLOC_QTY for all project years. This is a temporary, initial solution, however, based on partial information from this week's allocation meeting with SJRWMD. We need to confirm:

  • What are the units of the values stored in ALLOC_QTY?
  • What is the role of the YEAR_NO column, specifically with respect to interpreting ALLOC_QTY values?

For additional context and related questions, see attached 2015-09-25 email from Michael to Nishith.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 01/Oct/15 ]

Met with Yamila and Craig and learned:

PROJECT_ALLOCATION_GPD

  • _Average _GPD across whole permit
  • Actual permitted (not derived) value

PROJECT_ALLOCATION_MONTHLY

  • _Maximum _monthly withdrawal across whole permit, in gallons
    • Because maximum and not average, this is not simply PROJECT_ALLOCATION_GPD * Days In Month
  • Actual permitted (not derived) value
    • For NWFWMD permits only
    • SJRWMD equivalent is yearly limit, in millions of gallons
    • Reflects actual difference in real-world permits, not just computer systems

STATION_ALLOCATION_GPD

  • Assigned by system (not permitted explicitly)
    • Based on project-level allocations and pump capacities
  • Usually the same for all years, but can vary year-by-year for "tiered permit"
  • Values used by modelers, not for permitting
  • Safe to average across permit years for arriving at a single value to use in the DATABASES_STATION feature class
    • Make note in metadata, and refer users to eReg for yearly details (MCM: JUST UPDATED METADATA NOW)

PROJ_PRPTY_CUP

  • Contrary to earlier notes, this describes the primary water use for the organization, not the organization's business
  • Types are defined by the rules (i.e. real-world regulatory rules, not computer system rules)
  • Example: Agriculture is primary water use, but large consumer may produce enough water for public consumption to be considered a public water supply as a secondary use
  • NWFWMD only uses two levels - primary and secondary
    • Only include PROJ_USE_TP_CD and PROJ_USE_SUB_1_TP_CD in feature class, not SUB_2 and SUB_3
    • Name "PROJECT_PRIMARY_USE" and "PROJECT_SECONDARY_USE", respectively

Station-level uses

  • Optional
  • When assigned, assignments made at Site-Source level
    • One or more stations for that Site-Source are selected in eReg to apply the assignment to
    • eReg computes allocation by use at station level
    • Users never type in station-level quotas
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 01/Oct/15 ]

Related changes from same meeting require updates to PROJECT_BUSINESS_USE column. See associated issues.

[NWFWMDDI-24] Change refresh procedures to avoid single bad row from causing entire batch INSERT to fail Created: 14/Sep/15  Updated: 14/Sep/15  Resolved: 14/Sep/15

Status: To Do
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Replication
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Unresolved Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

With INSERT INTO ... SELECT, a single bad row will cause the whole INSERT batch to fail. We currently mitigate this by filtering for valid input rows (e.g. coordinates, datum codes, coordinate format codes), but unexpected issues can still occur. Ideally, only the bad row(s) would fail, and the remaining good rows would load.

Oracle 10.2+ supports the LOG ERRORS ... REJECT LIMIT UNLIMITED syntax, but this doesn't work with the SDE.ST_POINT() constructor (though unclear why).

The only other alternative appears to be row-by-row processing, which may be too slow in this environment (e.g. remote data source over WAN, high-overhead shape constructor). Tom Kyte evaluates various approaches from a performance perspective at: https://asktom.oracle.com/pls/asktom/f?p=100:11:::::P11_QUESTION_ID:455220177497.

Ideally, source data would be validated better on input. Our proposed data integrity project would also address this (if executed). At present, however, we need to accommodate low integrity coordinate values from NWPROD.



[NWFWMDDI-23] Evaluate use of GIS.GIS_REFRESH.GET_PERMIT_TYPE Created: 12/Sep/15  Updated: 27/Sep/15  Resolved: 27/Sep/15

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Replication
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Enhancement Priority: Minor
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Fixed Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

The REGUSER.REG_PROJ_ET.FULL_APP_NO value is a composite of four other values. Three of them (components 2-4) can be fetched from other columns in the database. The first component, however, is a special, coded representation of the rule/permit type that appears to be used only in FULL_APP_NO.

Unlike other coded values in NWPROD, the first component of FULL_APP_NO is created using a stored procedure, rather than a lookup table. Specifically, the internal codes for the FAC_RULE_ID value are translated by that procedure into the (shorter? more obvious?) codes used in FULL_APP_NO.

In the GIS.DATABASES_PROJECT_SITE feature class, we include both the FULL_APP_NO value (PROJECT_NUMBER), as well as the four individual components (PERMIT_TYPE, COUNTY_FIPS, OFFICIAL_PERMIT_NUMBER, and SEQUENCE_NUMBER) to assist users in sorting/filtering for different workflows.

To obtain the PERMIT_TYPE value, however, we currently rely on a static mapping in our GIS.GIS_REFRESH.GET_PERMIT_TYPE function. The drawback to this solution is that the mapping in GET_PERMIT_TYPE is decoupled from any changes in the master procedure in NWPROD, so that if the official mapping changes, our procedure will be out-of-date until someone recognizes and fixes the issue.

A better solution would be to call the official mapping procedure in NWPROD, directly. This way, our individual PERMIT_TYPE value will always be consistent with the composite FULL_APP_NO value, even as rule types change over time.

It may not be possible for us to call the official procedure directly, though. For one, our NWPROD ANONYMOUS user may not have access. Or, that procedure may not return the information we need in a format that is useful - for example, it may return a fully-formed FULL_APP_NO, rather than just the first component that we are seeking.

Therefore, if it is not possible/practical to call the official procedure in NWPROD, it might be advisable to change how GET_PERMIT_TYPE works in order to parse the first component from FULL_APP_NO, rather than deriving it from it's static mapping.

I sent Nishith an email today (2015-09-12) on this topic, and will make a decision on how to proceed when I hear back from him.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 27/Sep/15 ]

In a 2015-09-25 meeting with Nishith, he confirmed that a procedure/function does not exist in NWPROD to return the first FULL_APP_NO component alone. He concurred that the best way to retrieve this component - and, indeed, all four FULL_APP_NO components - was to parse FULL_APP_NO directly.

Resolve this issue by replacing GET_PERMIT_TYPE with a general-purpose function, or suite of functions, to extract the four components from FULL_APP_NO.

Comment by Michael Mannion [ 27/Sep/15 ]
  • Added function GIS.GIS_REFRESH.PARSE_FULL_APP_NO
  • Removed function GIS.GIS_REFRESH.GET_PERMIT_TYPE
  • Changed SQL for GIS.DATABASES_ERP_SITE and GIS.DATABASES_STATION to use PARSE_FULL_APP_NO to derive four FULL_APP_NO/PROJECT_NUMBER components

[NWFWMDDI-20] Identify invalid coordinates Created: 08/Sep/15  Updated: 08/Sep/15

Components: Data Integrity, Replication

Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Unresolved Votes: 0
Labels: None

Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

Per the 2015-09-02 meeting with SJRWMD, for at least some coordinates, users can enter coordinate values in the eReg user interface via text boxes that do not validate the coordinate structure. This can lead to typos in the UI to be stored in NWPROD, as well as mismatches between the coordinate code (e.g. UTM, DMS, DD) and the actual coordinate format).

The current refresh SQL for the derived data sets accommodates invalid coordinates by storing a row of attributes with a NULL shape, if the coordinates cannot be interpreted. GIS end users may not realize that this is occurring, though, because there is no obvious evidence of this condition in their maps. We should detect and report these conditions to the appropriate data custodian can investigate and resolve the underlying coordinate issues.

[NWFWMDDI-17] What are the details of the relationships betweten Projects/Stations and Water Bodies? Created: 25/Aug/15  Updated: 26/Sep/15  Resolved: 26/Sep/15

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Database
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Question Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Answered Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified

Attachments: FW fields.msg     logical.png     physical.png    

 Description   

Based on currently available information, Projects and Stations are associated with their respective Water Bodies through a complex series of relationships. In order to write correct and reliable SQL for the derived data set refresh procedures, we need to understand these relationships in more detail. This issue consolidates a series of questions pertaining to water body relationships.

Concepts

Our initial understanding comes from a 2015-08-10 email from Nishith (attached), specifically in the comments for the WUP.CU_SURFACE.WATER_SOURCE column:

If the water source is from the master list of sources in reguser.wtr_bdy_et then the source name and wtr_bdy_id is stored in reguser.proj_wtr_srce which links it to the project. Proj_wtr_srce_id in reguser.proj_stn links water source to the stn_id in reguser.proj_stn. If the source is not in the master list, the name of the source is stored in the reguser.proj_wtr_srce and the wtr_bdy_id is null

From this, we learn that:

  • There are three primary entities participating in these relationships:
    • Projects
    • Stations
    • Water Bodies (a.k.a. Water Sources)
  • Projects can be associated with Water Bodies
  • Stations can be associated with Water Bodies

And, we already know that:

  • Stations can be associated with Projects

Based on the above, combined with the general information we've learned from working with the system, we understand the cardinality of these relationships to be as follows:

Projects

  • A Project can be associated with zero, one, or many Water Bodies
  • A Project can be associated with zero, one, or many Stations

Stations

  • A Station can be associated with zero or one Project
  • A Station can be associated with zero or one Water Body

Water Bodies

  • A Water Body can be associated with zero, one, or many Projects
  • A Water Body can be associated with zero, one, or many Stations

These relationships are illustrated in the following diagram:

  • QUESTION 1: Is our conceptual understanding described above correct?

The remaining questions in this issue assume that the conceptual understanding described above is correct. If it is not, we will update or strike questions below, as appropriate. The next series of questions are also conceptual in nature; questions about the implementation of these entities within the NWPROD database are included in the following section.

Firstly, the composite Question 2 below explores the business rules governing Water Bodies that are associated at the Project and/or Station level:

  • QUESTION 2: What are the rules governing how Water Bodies are associated with Projects and Stations, such as:
    • 2.a: For a Project with Stations, must a Water Body that is associated with the Project also be associated with one of it's Stations, or can it be associated with the Project, alone?
    • 2.b: For a Station that is associated with a Project, must a Water Body that is associated with the Station also be associated with it's Project, or can it be associated with the Station, alone?
    • 2.c: For a standalone Station, may that station be associated with a Water Body?

Next, the email excerpt quoted above differentiates between Water Bodies that are part of a "master list" and those that are not. The following questions explore this topic:

  • QUESTION 3: Under what circumstances is a Water Body included in the master list of water sources, and when is the water body not included?
  • QUESTION 4: How is the master list of Water Bodies maintained (i.e. who is responsible, what is the workflow, what software is used)?
  • QUESTION 5: Under what circumstances may a user associate a Project or Station with a Water Body that is not part of the master list (e.g. at will, after manager approval)?

Implementation

This section discusses the implementation of the concepts above within the NWPROD database. For reference, the diagram below (physical.png) illustrates the primary tables pertaining to Projects, Stations, and Water Bodies, as well as the intermediate tables and foreign key relationships that associate them.

Note that this diagram includes only the primary and foreign keys that identify the entities and the relationships between them. Each table contains numerous additional attributes to describe the entities and their relationships.

Based on these relationships defined in NWPROD, we have the following observations and questions.

Firstly, the main Water Bodies table (REGUSER.WTR_BDY_ET) and the table that relates Projects to Water Bodies (REGUSER.PROJ_WTR_SRCE) contain seemingly duplicate information:

WTR_BDY_ET column PROJ_WTR_SRCE column
WTR_BDY_NM SRCE_NM
WTR_BDY_TP_CD SRCE_TP_CD
WTR_BDY_CTGRY_ID SRCE_CTGRY_ID

From the email excerpt quoted above, we understand that the former are for well-known Water Bodies in the "master list", and the latter is for Water Bodies that are not in the master list. Following from Questions 3-5 above:

  • QUESTION 6: Regarding the name/type/category columns in the REGUSER.WTR_BDY_ET and REGUSER.PROJ_WTR_SRCE tables:
    • 6.a: Are these columns mutually exclusive, or are there scenarios in which the corresponding columns in both tables could be populated?
    • 6.b: If they are mutually exclusive, what software enforces that exclusivity (e.g. web service, stored procedure, eReg UI)?
    • 6.c: If they are not mutually exclusive, can we consider one set of attributes primary, and display those for the consumer of a derived data set when both sets of attributes are populated?

Next, we find two paths by which a Station can be associated with a Water Body:

  • Directly, via SJR.STN_ET.WTR_BDY_ID (enforced by REGUSER.STN_ET_FK3 foreign key constraint)
  • Indirectly, via THE REGUSER.PROJ_STN table (PROJ_WTR_SRCE_ID column, enforced by REGUSER.PROJ_STN_FK6 foreign key constraint)

Given these two options:

  • QUESTION 7: Under what circumstances is a Station associated directly with a Water Body, and when is it associated indirectly?

When exploring the existing data in these tables, we find that some Stations are associated with Water Bodies via both direct and indirect relationships. As of 2015-08-26, there are 391 such cases:

SQL> SELECT
  2     COUNT(*)
  3  FROM sjr.stn_et se
  4  INNER JOIN reguser.proj_stn ps
  5     ON
  6             se.stn_id = ps.stn_id
  7  WHERE
  8     se.wtr_bdy_id IS NOT NULL -- Direct relationship to Water Body
  9     AND ps.proj_wtr_srce_id IS NOT NULL -- Indirect relationship to Water Body
 10  ;

  COUNT(*)
----------
       391

1 row selected.

This raises the question:

  • QUESTION 8: For Stations that are associated with Water Bodies via both direct and indirect relationships simultaneously:?
    • 8.a: Is this multiple-relationship scenario intentional and, if so, what type of real-world use case does it support?
    • 8.b: If this type of multiple-relationship is not intentional, what options do we have for correcting the existing data and preventing similar occurrences in the future?

In most cases, these multiple-relationship cases appear to be benign, in that both the direct and indirect path lead to the same Water Body. There are currently six cases, however, where the relationships lead to different Water Bodies for the same Station:

SQL> SELECT
  2     se.stn_id
  3     ,se.stn_nm
  4     ,wbe1.wtr_bdy_id indirect_wtr_bdy_id
  5     ,wbe1.wtr_bdy_nm indirect_wtr_bdy_nm
  6     ,wbe2.wtr_bdy_id direct_wtr_bdy_id
  7     ,wbe2.wtr_bdy_nm direct_wtr_bdy_nm
  8  FROM sjr.stn_et se
  9  LEFT JOIN reguser.proj_stn ps
 10     ON
 11             se.stn_id = ps.stn_id
 12  LEFT JOIN reguser.proj_wtr_srce pws
 13     ON
 14             ps.proj_wtr_srce_id = pws.proj_wtr_srce_id
 15  LEFT JOIN reguser.wtr_bdy_et wbe1
 16     ON
 17             pws.wtr_bdy_id = wbe1.wtr_bdy_id
 18  LEFT JOIN reguser.wtr_bdy_et wbe2
 19     ON
 20             se.wtr_bdy_id = wbe2.wtr_bdy_id
 21  WHERE
 22     wbe1.wtr_bdy_id != wbe2.wtr_bdy_id -- Same station references different water bodies in WTR_BDY_ET
 23     OR ( -- Same station references one water body in PROJ_WTR_SRC and another water body in WTR_BDY_ET
 24             pws.wtr_bdy_id IS NULL
 25             AND se.wtr_bdy_id IS NOT NULL
 26     )
 27  ;

Similar to Question 8 above, but limited to these (currently) six special cases:

  • QUESTION 9: For Stations that are associated with different Water Bodies via direct and indirect relationships simultaneously:
    • 9.a: Is this scenario intentional and, if so, what type of real-world use case does it support?
    • 9.b: If this is not intentional, what options do we have for correcting the existing data and preventing similar occurrences in the future?

On a different topic related to data integrity, we consider the case of indirect Station-Water Body relationships in more detail (note that the following comments/questions only pertain to indirect relationships, not direct ones). The relationships defined in the NWPROD database appear to implement the following model:

  • A Project is associated with a Water Body (via the REGUSER.PROJ_WTR_SRCE table)
  • A Station is associated with a Project (via the REGUSER.PROJ_STN table)
  • A Project-Station instance is associated with a Project-Water Body instance (via the REGUSER.PROJ_STN.PROJ_WTR_SRCE_ID column)

These relationships can be cumbersome to describe in prose, but should be evident from reviewing the attached ERD excerpt, physical.png. The salient point is that in this indirect scenario, the two intermediate join tables - REGUSER.PROJ_STN and REGUSER.PROJ_WTR_SRCE - create the relationship between Stations and Water Bodies.

Engaging in a bit of speculation, this design may be intended to enforce that both the Station and Water Body are associated with the same Project. For example, if Michael's Project is associated with North Pond, and Yamila's Project is associated with South Pond, it may be the intent that any Station associated with Michael's Project can only be associated with North Pond, and not South Pond.

The existing data model does not appear to enforce this condition. Instead, the REGUSER.PROJ_STN_FK6 foreign key constraint only ensures that a Station relates to a Water Body that is associated with any Project, not necessarily with it's own parent Project.

To enforce that a Station and Project reference the same Water Body, the REGUSER.PROJ_STN_FK6 constraint would need to include the CUR_ID column, in addition to the existing PROJ_WTR_SRCE_ID column. This would guarantee that a Station could only relate to a Water Body that is already associated with the same Project - that is, with the same CUR_ID.

Note that in the existing data, all of the indirect relationships are "valid", in that the Station and the Water Body share a common Project, despite that the database is not enforcing this condition.

Considering both the facts and the hypotheses above:

  • QUESTION 10: In the case of an indirect Station-Water Body relationship:
    • 10.a: Is it permissible for the Station to be associated with a Water Body that is not associated with its own parent Project?
    • 10.b: If not, is this condition being enforced by another piece of software (e.g. web service, eReg UI), and could we modify the REGUSER.PROJ_STN_FK6 constraint to cause NWPROD to enforce that condition?

With respect to Question 10.b, note that our intent is not to modify NWPROD for its own sake, but rather to support our own data sets that are derived from NWPROD content. We create and refresh our derived data sets at the SQL level and, where business rules are not specifically enforced within the database, our SQL is necessarily more complex in order to detect and accommodate special cases that may arise (e.g. different Projects for a Station and its Water Body). This does not imply that all business rules should be enforced within the database, only that ones that can easily be enforced at that level using core components, such as composite foreign keys, may warrant such consideration.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 26/Sep/15 ]

We answered these questions in a 2015-09-02 meeting with SJRWMD.

ANSWER 1
Both projects and stations are associated with water sources through the intermediate REGUSER.PROJ_STN table. In this way, projects/stations are not inherently associated with water sources. Rather, instances of stations that are associated with projects are, in turn, associated with water sources.

With respect to cardinality, one project-station instance can be associated with zero or one water source, per the PROJ_STN table constraints. In reality, the eReg application imposes additional constraints, beyond those implemented at the database level, such as ensuring valid combinations of projects/stations/water sources, and ensuring that stations are associated with both a project and site before a permit is issued.

ANSWER 2
Per ANSWER 1 above, only project-station instances in REGUSER.PROJ_STN are associated with water bodies. The direct path from SJR.STN_ET.WTR_BDY_ID (enforced by STN_ET_FK3) is not used by eReg, per Nishith. Therefore, the entirety of QUESTION 2 is answered by virtue of the fact that projects and stations associate with water bodies exclusively via PROJ_STN.

ANSWER 3
ANSWER 4
The master list of known water bodies is managed by SJRWMD. During the conversation, it became obvious that the means by which this list is curated is not relevant to our work at-hand, so we did not pursue a more specific answer to these questions.

ANSWER 5
Groundwater sources must always be present in the master list. Surface water sources may be in the master list, or may be created at-will by the eReg user. Non-master surface water sources may be described as simply as "Pond", or other generic names for a minor / unnamed water body.

ANSWER 6
Project-station instances only reference water sources stored in PROJ_WTR_SRCE. eReg uses the master WTR_BDY_ET table when looking up known water sources to present to the user, but copies that information into PROJ_WTR_SRCE when selected. The reason that the water source data is copied to PROJ_WTR_SRCE is to persist the information as it existed at the time of the assignment, and to decouple it from future changes to the WTR_BDY_ET table.

ANSWER 7
ANSWER 8
ANSWER 9
ANSWER 10
For our purposes (e.g. within eReg), stations are only associated with water sources as part of a project-station pair (e.g. PROJ_STN table). Stations are not associated directly with water sources. Per Nishith, the STN_ET.WTR_BDY_ID column should be ignored.

[NWFWMDDI-13] For projects, how do primary/other use types work in NWPROD? Created: 19/Aug/15  Updated: 26/Sep/15  Resolved: 26/Sep/15

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Database
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Question Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Answered Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Description   

Observations that we want to understand better:

  • In REGUSER.PROJ_PRPTY_CUP, there are 4 columns for primary/other use codes: PROJ_USE_TP_CD for primary, and PROJ_USE_SUB_<n>_TP_CD for other, where <n> is 1-3. Every row has a primary code. Some rows have a SUB_1 code. No rows have SUB_2 or SUB_3 codes.
  • In the legacy database, many projects had multiple other uses (e.g. SUB_1 through SUB_3), but none have multiple other uses in NWPROD.
  • The legacy database had 35 use codes. NWPROD has 8 use codes. NW users may need more detail than this.
  • The more general nature of the NWPROD use codes may be the reason that the SUB_2 and SUB_3 columns aren't used - they may not need to be used, because SUB_1 covers all of the other use types.
  • The PROJ_USE_TP_CMMT_TXT column has concatenated text containing the legacy values, in the format "Primary use: <p>\nOther uses:<o>[,<o>]" where <p> is the 2-letter legacy code for the primary use, and <o> is a list of zero or more 2-letter legacy codes for other uses.

 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 20/Aug/15 ]

Include in this discussion new columns (e.g. WATER_USE at station level) to be added during August end-of-month update.

Comment by Michael Mannion [ 26/Sep/15 ]

Per a 2015-09-25 meeting with SJRWMD, Nishith and Marlise explained the following:

  • The REGUSER.PROJ_PRPTY_CUP table stores the business use of the organization to which the permit was issued. The REGUSER.REG_ALLOC table stores the water use allowed by the permit. An example would be a business use of "Church", with a water use of "Irrigation" for the church lawn. (Note that a "Church" business use does not exist in the database at present. Additionally, the detailed descriptions of the business use codes describe water uses. These findings are inconsistent with the discussion at the aforementioned meeting.)
  • The four use type codes in PROJ_PRPTY_CUP (PROJ_USE_TP_CD, PROJ_USE_SUB_<n>TP_CD where _<n> is 1-3) and in PROJ_ALLOC (USE_LVL_<n>TP_CD where _<n> is 1-4) are hierarchical descriptors, ranging from most general to most specific. Per Marlise, the same list of values is used in PROJ_PRPTY_CUP for the first two levels (with no values for the last two levels).
  • A project may have only one set of business use codes, stored in its single record in PROJ_PRPTY_CUP. The same project may have zero or more water use types listed in PROJ_ALLOC (one row per water use hierarchy). Note that legacy rows do not have water use values. Per Nishith, station-level water uses were not included in the legacy system, and in NWPROD, all allocations/uses are rolled up from the station > site > project level. Therefore, only new projects created in eReg will have water uses (or legacy projects that are updated via eReg).
  • The original list of legacy uses have been reduced to the existing list of NWPROD uses, in order to match the uses now available on the standardized State-wide permits.
  • We are intentionally excluding the legacy uses (PROJ_USE_TP_CMMT_TXT) from the derived data sets, in order for the derived contents to match those found in eReg.



[NWFWMDDI-12] How did REGUSER.REG_PROJ_ET.OFFCL_ID get populated during migration for each legacy data type (e.g. ERP, WUP) Created: 19/Aug/15  Updated: 26/Sep/15  Resolved: 26/Sep/15

Status: Done
Project: NWFWMD Data Integration
Components: Database
Affects versions: None
Fix versions: None

Type: Question Priority: Major
Reporter: Michael Mannion Assignee: Michael Mannion
Resolution: Answered Votes: 0
Labels: None
Remaining Estimate: Not Specified
Time Spent: Not Specified
Original estimate: Not Specified


 Comments   
Comment by Michael Mannion [ 26/Sep/15 ]

Per Nishith in 2015-09-02 meeting:

  • WUP was migrated first. CU_APP.APNUM was stored directly in CUR_ID. For the first sequence for a given permit, that CUR_ID was used for OFFCL_ID, which subsequently remained the same for all sequences of that permit.
  • ERP was migrated second. CUR_ID values were generated automatically by NWPROD (i.e. they were not migrated from a legacy value), starting with the next sequence value after the WUP migration. As with WUP - and as with all permits - the CUR_ID of the first sequence of a permit is used as the OFFCL_ID value for all subsequent sequences of that same permit.
